definition: Lenz DCC protocol with 7 bit short address
Lenz DCC protocol with 14 bit long address

A to B is allowed, B to A is not allowed

Returns the smallest integral value larger than or equal to `number`.
The log library provides 7 functions, each function takes all its arguments, concatenates them into a string then sends it to the Traintastic server log.
Additional values, all values are concatenated and seperated by a space.
Log a debug message, useful when developing or testing a script.
Additional values, all values are concatenated and seperated by a space.

Log a fatal message, use this for unrecoverble errors only.
Additional values, all values are concatenated and seperated by a space.

Get the class type of an object.
The object to get class type of.
The class type of `object`, or `nil` if `object` isn't a valid object.
Stop all vehicles and power off, identical to pressing power off in the Traintastic client application.
Stop all vehicles, identical to pressing stop in the Traintastic client application.
Object if it exists with the given `id`, else it returns `nil`.
Fired when the world state changes, e.g. when pressing the power on, power off, stop, run etc. button in the Traintastic client application or calling `world.stop()`.
User data that was set or `nil` if no user data was set during connect.
List of all object that are available in Traintastic Lua scripting.
List of all boards, it can be accessed using {ref:object.world#boards|`world.boards`}.
Curved left turnout left rail tile
The clock object represents the time of the world. There is only one clock object, it can be accessed using {ref:object.world#clock|`world.clock`}.
Interface for communicating with a LocoNet network.
Object id, each object has a unique id.
{ref:object.train} that is assigned to the block.
The block that the train is assigned to.
{ref:object.train} that is removed from the block.
The block that the train is removed from.
`true` if clock is frozen, the clock does not tick.
Fast clock multiplier rate. That is, one minute in real time represents `multiplier` minutes of world time.
`true` if clock is running, `false` if the clock is frozen or the world is not running.
Current time in ticks since midnight, each tick is one fast clock minute,  e.g. `383` is `6:23` (AM)
Fired when the clock is frozen or stopped.
Current time in ticks since midnight.
Current time in ticks since midnight.
Fired when the clock ticks, once every fast clock minute.
Current time in ticks since midnight.
`true` if interface is online, `false` otherwise. Read `status` for more information.
Current output value, a {ref:enum.tri_state} value. `TRUE` means high, `FALSE` means low, `UNDEFINED` means that the output value isn't known.
The output value to set, `true` means high, `false` means low.
`true` if request is sent, `false` otherwise. Note: It might take some time for the hardware to process the request.
Fired if the output value changes.
The new output value, `true` means high, `false` means low.
`true` if emergency stop is active, `false` otherwise.
`true` if the train's velocity is zero, `false` if the train's velocity is greater than zero.
`true` if the train contains a rail vehicle that can power the train, `false` otherwise.
Stop the train, sets the speed to zero.
World state, a combination of {ref:set.world_state} values.
World UUID, unique for each world.
World state, a combination of {ref:set.world_state} values.
Request the LocoNet command station to send a DCC packet to the track (`OPC_IMM_PACKET`). This isn't supported by all LocoNet command stations.
Table containing up to five DCC packet bytes to send excluding checksum byte.
Number of times to repeat the packet on the track. (1...7)
`true` if send to the command station, `false` otherwise.
Object at index or `nil` if index isn't valid.

This examples monitors the world state and controls an output based on the `RUN` flag. If the world is in `RUN` state the output is off, if the world is stopped the output is on, e.g. for controller a red lamp.
This example show how to use an input to control a direction control board element on the board. This can e.g. be used for physical control panels that control board elements.
Train direction from the block perspective.
Towards the west for horizontal blocks, towards the south for vertical blocks.
Towards the east for horizontal blocks, towards the north for vertical blocks.
Fired when a {ref:object.train} reserves the block.
Train direction from the block perspective, a {ref:enum.block_train_direction} value.
Fired when a {ref:object.train} enters the block.
Train direction from the block perspective, a {ref:enum.block_train_direction} value.
Fired when a {ref:object.train} has left the block.
The block that the train left.
Train direction from the block perspective, a {ref:enum.block_train_direction} value.

This examples shows how a signal can be controlled with DCCext commands (via LocoNet) as demonstration how custom control can be implemented. Traintastic will offcourse support DCCext natively in the future.
Output address, valid range depends on `channel`.
{ref:object.singleoutput}, {ref:object.pairoutput} or {ref:object.aspectoutput} object depending on `channel` or `nil` if `channel`/`address` combination is invalid.
Fired when the train enters a {ref:object.blockrailtile|block}.
Train direction from the block perspective, a {ref:enum.block_train_direction} value.
Fired when the train has left a {ref:object.blockrailtile|block}.
Train direction from the block perspective, a {ref:enum.block_train_direction} value.
A collection of examples to help getting started with Traintastic Lua scripting.

Interface for communicating with a Traintastic DIY compatible device.
Interface for communicating with a XpressNet network.
Interface for communicating with a Z21, z21 or z21 start.
